description_en: A detailed examination, analysis, or critical inspection of one or multiple subjects designed to discover facts.
A unique proper name or character sequence that identifies this particular study.
A name that designates this study.
The non-unique initials or abbreviated name used for identification.
A statement or piece of writing that provides details on this study.
The conditions which, if met, make an person eligible for participation in this study.
An investigator who is responsible for all aspects of the conduct of a study.
Name of study contact.
An email address for the purpose of contacting the study contact person.
A plan specification comprised of protocols (which may specify how and what kinds of data will be gathered) that are executed as part of this study.
The date on which this study began.

The date on which the concluding information for this study is completed. Usually, this is when the last subject has a final visit, or the main analysis has finished, or any other protocol-defined completion date.
The status of a study or trial.
An integer specifying the quantity of study subjects enrolled in the study at the current time.
An integer specifying the quantity of samples collected at the current time.
The act of making data or other structured information accessible to the public or to the user group of a database.
The act of making data or other structured information accessible to the public or to the user group of a database.
One or more characters used to identify, name, or characterize the nature, properties, or contents of a thing.
The words or language units by which a thing is known.
Persons who are observed, analyzed, examined, investigated, experimented upon, or/and treated in the course of a particular study.

A unique proper name or character sequence that identifies this particular individual who is the subject of personal data, persons to whom data refers, and from whom data are collected, processed, and stored.
A backup sequence of characters used to identify an entity.

A person's concept of self as being male and masculine or female and feminine, or ambivalent, based in part on physical characteristics, parental responses, and psychological and social pressures. It is the internal experience of gender role. For practical reasons the lookups are limited to first and second-level entries, but can be expanded when needed. Note that 'Gender at birth', 'Genotypic sex' and any (gender-related) hormone therapies in 'Medication' are usually medically more relevant than this term.

Assigned gender is one's gender which was assigned at birth, typically by a medical and/or legal organization, and then later registered with other organizations. Such a designation is typically based off of the superficial appearance of external genitalia present at birth.
A biological sex quality inhering in an individual based upon genotypic composition of sex chromosomes.
Country of residence at enrollment.
Population category defined using ancestry informative markers (AIMs) based on genetic/genomic data.
The country that this person was born in.
The year in which this person was born.
The calendar date on which a person was born.
A findings domain that contains general subject characteristics that are evaluated periodically to determine if they have changed.
The age at which death occurred.
The calendar date of subject's death.
The year in which an individual derived.
The most significant institute for medical consultation and/or study inclusion in context of the genetic disease of this person.
A person acting as a channel for communication between groups or on behalf of a group.
Email address of the contact person or organization
Material or data related to this person that is not captured by this system though known to be available in other institutes such as biobanks or hospitals.
Reference to the study or studies in which this person participates.
A domestic group, or a number of domestic groups linked through descent (demonstrated or stipulated) from a common ancestor, marriage, or adoption.
A designation that has some relationship to motherhood.
Having to do with the father, coming from the father, or related through the father.
Any individual related biologically or legally to another individual.
Either of two offspring born from the same pregnancy.
The date for the first patient visit.
Any tissue from a fetus.
Information on whether the patient is a child from two family members who are second cousins or closer.
Reference to the study or studies in which this person participates.
The act of making data or other structured information accessible to the public or to the user group of a database.
A group of individuals, identified by a common characteristic.
Findings and circumstances relating to the examination and treatment of a patient.
A unique proper name or character sequence that identifies this particular clinical examination.
An individual who is the subject of personal data, persons to whom data refers, and from whom data are collected, processed, and stored.
Individuals in a pedigree who exhibit the specific phenotype under study.
The date on which a diagnosis of disease was made.
The age (in years), measured from some defined time point (e.g. birth) at which a patient is diagnosed with a disease.
Age (in years) of onset of clinical manifestations related to the disease of the patient.
Age of the patient at the moment of the most recent screening.
The outward appearance of the individual. In medical context, these are often the symptoms caused by a disease.
Phenotypes or symptoms that were looked for but not observed, which may help in differential diagnosis or establish incomplete penetrance.

The test or procedure was successfully performed, but the results are borderline and can neither be declared positive / negative nor detected / not detected according to the current established criteria.
A diagnosis made from a study of the signs and symptoms of a disease.
Gene affected by pathogenic variation that is causal for disease of the patient.
Causal variant in HGVS notation with optional classification or free text explaining any other molecular mechanisms involved.

A drug product that contains one or more active and/or inactive ingredients used by the patient intended to treat, prevent or alleviate the symptoms of disease. Any hormone therapies, gender-related or otherwise, should also be recorded here.
The specific way a therapeutic drug is to be taken, including formulation, route of administration, dose, dosing interval, and treatment duration.
A record of a person's background regarding health, occurrence of disease events and surgical procedures.
Types of phenotypic data collected in a clinical setting that is potentially available upon request.
A condition or state at a particular time.
First contact of the patient with a specialised center in context of disease or study inclusion.
The particular day, month and year an event has happened or will happen.
The act of making data or other structured information accessible to the public or to the user group of a database.
Family members related by descent rather than by marriage or law who were diagnosed with the same condition as the individual who is the primary focus of investigation (i.e. the proband).
Family members related by descent rather than by marriage or law who were also tested by next-generation sequencing.
Patient's classification of functioning i.e. disability profile according to International Classification of Functioning and Disability (ICF).
This diagnosis c.q. clinical examination is based on one or more sampled materials.
A natural substance derived from living organisms such as cells, tissues, proteins, and DNA.
Name or other identifier of an entry from a biosample database.
A backup sequence of characters used to identify an entity.
Reference to the subject from whom this material was collected.
A sequence of letters, numbers, or other characters that specifically identifies a particular order.
The act of making data or other structured information accessible to the public or to the user group of a database.
Reference to a diagnosis c.q. clinical examination of which this material may be a part of. There can be multiple diagnoses when a non-tumor material is reused as reference.
The date on which the activity or entity was ordered.
The explanation for why a test, measurement, or assessment is executed.
The date that a sample was collected or obtained.
Date and time at which this material was collected.
Date and time at which this material was listed or recorded officially, i.e. officially qualified or enrolled.
The procedure whereby this material was sampled for an analysis.
The procedure whereby this material was sampled for an analysis.

A variation from processes or procedures defined in the sampling protocol. Deviations usually do not preclude the overall evaluability of subject data for either efficacy or safety, and are often acknowledged and accepted in advance by the sponsor.
The rationale for why a deviation from the sampling protocol has occurred.
The type of material taken from a biological entity for testing, diagnostic, propagation, treatment or research purposes.
Biological entity that constitutes the structural organization of an individual member of a biological species from which this material was taken.
The pathological state of the tissue from which this material was derived.
An indication as to whether a biospecimen is suitable for testing purposes.
The conditions under which this biological material was stored.
The date beyond which this material is no longer regarded as fit for use.
The percentage of tumor cells compared to total cells present in this material.

A place on the Earth where this material is located, by its name or by its geographical location. This definition is intentionally vague to allow reuse locally (e.g. which freezer), for contacting (e.g. which institute), broadly for logistical or legal reasons (e.g. city, country or continent).
Reports the existence of any analyses performed on this material other than genomics (e.g. transcriptomics, metabolomics, proteomics).
Indicate if this material was produced from or related to another.
Describes the procedure whereby biological samples for an experiment are sourced.
One or more characters used to identify, name, or characterize the nature, properties, or contents of a thing.
The words or language units by which a thing is known.
A written or verbal account, representation, statement, or explanation of something.
A form or variant of a type or original; one of a sequence of copies of a program, each incorporating new modifications.
A unique symbol that establishes identity of the resource.
A sample preparation for a nucleic acids sequencing assay.
A unique proper name or character sequence that identifies this particular sample preparation.
Reference to the source material from which this sample was prepared.
Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting.
A sequence of letters, numbers, or other characters that specifically identifies a particular order.
Amount of input material in nanogram (ng).

Pre-filled, ready-to-use reagent cartridges intented to improve chemistry, cluster density and read length as well as improve quality (Q) scores for this sample. Reagent components are encoded to interact with the sequencing system to validate compatibility with user-defined applications.

Indicates whether a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) was used to prepare this sample. PCR is a method for amplifying a DNA base sequence using multiple rounds of heat denaturation of the DNA and annealing of oligonucleotide primers complementary to flanking regions in the presence of a heat-stable polymerase.

Indicates which target enrichment kit was used to prepare this sample. Target enrichment is a pre-sequencing DNA preparation step where DNA sequences are either directly amplified (amplicon or multiplex PCR-based) or captured (hybrid capture-based) in order to only focus on specific regions of a genome or DNA sample.
Indicates whether any unique molecular identifiers (UMIs) are present. An UMI barcode is a short nucleotide sequence that is used to identify reads originating from an individual mRNA molecule.

In paired-end sequencing, the DNA between the adapter sequences is the insert. The length of this sequence is known as the insert size, not to be confused with the inner distance between reads. So, fragment length equals read adapter length (2x) plus insert size, and insert size equals read lenght (2x) plus inner distance.
The number of nucleotides intended to be ordered from each side of a nucleic acid fragment obtained after the completion of a sequencing process.
A machine-readable representation of information in a visual format on a surface.
A quantity of people or things treated or regarded as a group, especially when subdivided from a larger group.
The act of making data or other structured information accessible to the public or to the user group of a database.
Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting.
A character or string that represents the short code name of the laboratory test.
A character or string that represents the full name of the laboratory assessment.
A written or verbal account, representation, statement, or explanation of something
A classification of the laboratory test.
A sub-division of the laboratory test classification.
A data set of the names or identifiers of genes that are the outcome of an analysis or have been put together for the purpose of an analysis.
The determination of complete (typically nucleotide) sequences, including those of genomes (full genome sequencing, de novo sequencing and resequencing), amplicons and transcriptomes.
A unique proper name or character sequence that identifies this particular nucleic acid sequencing assay.
Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting.
Reference to the prepared sample, i.e. the source that was sequenced.
A rationale for executing a plan of action.
Date on which this sequencing assay was performed.
An organization that provides sequence determination service.
The used sequencing platform (i.e. brand, name of a company that produces sequencer equipment).
The used product name and model number of a manufacturer's genomic (dna) sequencer.
Method used to determine the order of bases in a nucleic acid sequence.
The median number of times a particular locus (site, nucleotide, amplicon, region) was sequenced.
The number of nucleotides successfully ordered from each side of a nucleic acid fragment obtained after the completion of a sequencing process.

In paired-end sequencing, the DNA between the adapter sequences is the insert. The length of this sequence is known as the insert size, not to be confused with the inner distance between reads. So, fragment length equals read adapter length (2x) plus insert size, and insert size equals read lenght (2x) plus inner distance.
Percentage of reads with a Phred quality score over 30, which indicates less than a 1/1000 chance that the base was called incorrectly.
Percentage of the target sequence on which 20 or more unique reads were successfully mapped.

Other NGS quality control metrics, including but not limited to (i) sequencer metrics such as yield, error rate, density (K/mm2), cluster PF (%) and phas/prephas (%), (ii) alignment metrics such as QM insert size, GC content, QM duplicated reads (%), QM error rate, uniformity/evenness of coverage and maternal cell contamination, and (iii) variant call metrics such as number of SNVs/CNVs/SVs called, number of missense/nonsense variants, common variants (%), unique variants (%), gender match and trio inheritance check.
The act of making data or other structured information accessible to the public or to the user group of a database.
A set of related records (either written or electronic) kept together.
The literal identifier for an electronic file.
A unique proper name or character sequence that identifies this particular nucleic acid sequencing assay.
An individual who is the subject of personal data, persons to whom data refers, and from whom data are collected, processed, and stored.
Reference to the study or studies to which this file belongs.
A group of individuals, identified by a common characteristic.
A computer which provides some service for other computers connected to it via a network.
The specification of a node (file or directory) in a hierarchical file system, usually specified by listing the nodes top-down.
The format of an electronic file.
The size of an electronic file in bytes.
A 32-character hexadecimal number that is computed on a file.
The condition for an electronic file relative to the current data or file processing step.
The date a digital resource was created.
A backup sequence of characters used to identify an entity.
The act of making data or other structured information accessible to the public or to the user group of a database.
A group of individuals, identified by a common characteristic.
One or more characters used to identify, name, or characterize the nature, properties, or contents of a thing.
The non-unique initials or abbreviated name used for identification.
The words or language units by which a thing is known.
The description of the characteristics that define a cohort.
The principle investigator or responsible person for this study.
A person acting as a channel for communication between groups or on behalf of a group.
An email address for the purpose of contacting the study contact person.
A subset of a larger population, selected for investigation to draw conclusions or make estimates about the larger population.

Consent given by a patient to a surgical or medical procedure or participation in a study, examination or analysis after achieving an understanding of the relevant medical facts and the risks involved.
A unique proper name or character sequence that identifies this particular signed individual consent.
Reference to the person (i.e. subject) to whom this individual consent applies.

Reference to the informed consent form that was signed. Points to a particular instance of leaflet and consent form that usually exists as a record (i.e. a row) within the same database as this individual consent.
Indicates the person, group, or institution who performed the collection act.
A date specification that designates when this individual consent form was signed.
Starting date of the validity of this individual consent.
End date of the validity of this individual consent.
An individual who is authorized under applicable State or local law to consent on behalf of a child or incapable person to general medical care including participation in clinical research.
An indication that the consent to participate in the study or one or more segments of the study has been revoked.
A data item that is used to indicate consent permissions for datasets and/or materials, and relates to the purposes for which datasets and/or material might be used.
Data use modifiers indicate additional conditions for use. For instance, a dataset is restricted to investigations into specific diseases or performed at specific geographical locations.

Further specification of applied data use permissions and modifiers. For example, a list of countries in case of geographic restrictions or a list of diseases when restricted to disease-specific research.
Permission is given for MatchMaking
The procedure of recontacting the patient for specified reasons. This means the patient agrees to be re-identifiable under those circumstances.
The act of making data or other structured information accessible to the public or to the user group of a database.

A document explaining all the relevant information to assist an individual in understanding the expectations and risks in making a decision about a procedure. This document is presented to and signed by the individual or guardian.
A title or name given to the leaflet that belongs to this consent form.
A point or period of time associated with the publication of this leaflet that belongs to this consent form.
The version, edition, or adaptation of this leaflet that belongs to this consent form.

A unique proper name or character sequence that identifies this particular leaflet and consent form combination used in signing individual consent. Using a DOI would be optimal. Using any resolvable URL is suboptimal but still preferable over using a plain text value.
A title or name given to this consent form.
Date of acceptance of this consent form.
End date of the validity of this consent form.
Indicates the authoritative body who brought this consent form into existence.
The version, edition, or adaptation of this consent form.
An analysis applies analytical (often computational) methods to existing data of a specific type to produce some desired output.
A unique proper name or character sequence that identifies this particular analysis.
Reference to the sequencing that was performed, i.e. the source on which this analysis was based.

A place on the Earth where the data is located, by its name or by its geographical location. This definition is intentionally vague to allow reuse locally (e.g. which computer), for contacting (e.g. which institute), broadly for logistical or legal reasons (e.g. city, country or continent).
The file location of the data, or a copy of the data, on an electronically accessible device for preservation (either in plain-text or encrypted format).
Which data file formats (i.e. defined ways or layouts of representing and structuring data in a computer file, blob, string, message, or elsewhere) are stored and potentially available.
Any used problem-solving procedures implemented in software to be executed by a computer.
The specific build of the human genome used as reference for sequence alignment and variant calling.

A human-readable collection of information about about how a scientific experiment or analysis was carried out that results in a specific set of data or results used for further analysis or to test a specific hypothesis.

A variation from processes or procedures defined in the bioinformatic protocol. Deviations usually do not preclude the overall evaluability of subject data for either efficacy or safety, and are often acknowledged and accepted in advance by the sponsor.
The rationale for why a deviation from the bioinformatic protocol has occurred.

Any followed systematic statement of policy rules or principles. Guidelines may be developed by government agencies at any level, institutions, professional societies, governing boards, or by convening expert panels.
A metabolomics material processing is a protocol application including material enrollments and biomaterial transformations.
A unique proper name or character sequence that identifies this particular metabolomics material processing.
The transfer of a solute from a liquid phase to another immiscible or partially-miscible liquid phase in contact with it.
The filter used in separating of suspended solids from a liquid or gas, usually by forcing a carrier gas or liquid through a porous medium.
The volume of carrier gas passing through a chromatography column in unit time.
A sample preparation technique using a solid adsorbent contained most commonly in a cartridge device, or on a disk to adsorb select species from solution.
Washing is a process by which a material entity acting as contaminant (e.g. excess staining reagent) is removed by application of one or more cycles of solution in flow.
A qualitative or quantitative analysis performed to determine the amount of a particular constituent in a sample or the biological or pharmacological properties of a drug.
A unique proper name or character sequence that identifies this particular metabolomics assay.
This metabolomic assay is part of a metabolomic material processing.
A valve that controls the flow of fluids in through the wall of a chamber.
A piece of apparatus that consists of at least an ion source, a mass-to-charge analyser, a detector and a vacuum system and is used to measure mass spectra.
A piece of apparatus that takes an analyte and generates ions which are passed to the rest of a mass spectrometer for analysis.
A piece of apparatus that has the form of a tube with a diameter between 5 to 50 mm and hosts the stationary bed in chromatography.
Any method for the synthesis of polymer membranes that involves the polymer transforming from the liquid phase of the cast solution to the solid phase.
Condition in which variables of the experiment are manipulated to determine the variables effect by comparing to a control condition.
Basic information, annotation or documentation concerning a metabolomics analysis workflow (but not the workflow itself).
A unique proper name or character sequence that identifies this particular metabolomics assay.
This metabolomic analysis is part of a metabolomic assay.
File content or location that encapsulates the analysis workflow, i.e. a sequence of operations to achieve one or more objectives.
The engine used to execute the workflow such as Papermill, Jupyter, Galaxy or Nextflow.
A printed or electronic work offered for distribution.
The analysis has been boxed by a container engine such as Singularity or Docker.
A general term primarily used for digitally stored data such as computer programs and other kinds of information read and written by computers.
Any factor that defines a system and determines (or limits) its performance.
Which data file formats (i.e. defined ways or layouts of representing and structuring data in a computer file, blob, string, message, or elsewhere) are stored and potentially available.
Any socially-agreed upon specifications used such as Common Workflow Language, mzML, ISA-TAB, FAIR Genomes, etc.
A method of analyzing or representing statistical data or a procedure for calculating a statistic, such as principal component analysis, affinity propagation clustering, T-test, etc.
Schema for a Beacon genomic variant entry.
A unique proper name or character sequence that identifies this particular variation.
An allele that varies in it sequence from what is considered the reference or canonical sequence at that location.
An attribute inhering in a feature that is designated to serve as a standard against which 'variant' versions of the same location are compared.
An attribute describing a type of variation inhering in a sequence feature or collection.
The starting position of a sequence feature or interval.
The ending position of a sequence feature or interval.
The specific build of the human genome used as reference for this variant.
TODO unsure what is ment here - Refseq accession number of a transcript?
NCBI resource that aggregates information about genomic variation and its relationship to human health.
HGVS genomic sequence variant nomenclature
HGVS protein sequence variant nomenclature
HGVS transcript sequence variant nomenclature
A backup sequence of characters used to identify an entity.
A variation in the amino acid sequence of a specific gene product.
A unique gene name within a specific repository, database, or collection.
A sequence feature (continuous extent of biological sequence) that is of genomic origin (i.e. carries sequence from the genome of a cell or organism)
The effect that the variant has on each feature that it overlaps. A variant will have a consequence for each feature that it overlaps.
The determination of the meaning of a clinical result.
The likelihood of an entity to produce pathologic changes or disease.
